awd_titl_txt: Measuring Mindset in Undergraduate STEM Students
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to develop a rigorous, evidence-based survey to measure the "mindset" of  undergraduate STEM students.  Mindset is a psychological trait that may influence student success and persistence.  The mindset construct refers to whether a student believes that intelligence is a trait that is innate and unchangeable (called a fixed mindset) or malleable and improvable (called a growth mindset). When students struggle academically, it has been shown that those with a growth mindset are more likely to take action to improve their performance, while those with a fixed mindset are more likely to give up or accept low performance. Many student success initiatives have attempted to leverage the effects of mindset to improve student success by conducting interventions to encourage students to adopt a growth mindset. However, these interventions have had varied success. One reason for this variable success may be that the survey used to measure mindset does not work well with undergraduate students.  If so, survey results will have limited ability to measure the effectiveness and outcomes of mindset interventions. Preliminary research by the the principal investigator of this project supports the possibility that the existing mindset survey may not work well with undergraduate students.  It suggests that the variability results because undergraduates interpret the survey questions in multiple ways. The goal of this project is to develop and validate a new survey to measure mindset in undergraduate STEM students. Additionally, this project will provide support for the principal investigator, a new STEM educational researcher, to learn about the psychometrics needed to conduct this work. This professional development will include graduate classes in statistics and collaboration/mentorship from experts in psychometrics and statistics.

The goal of this project is to develop and validate a new mindset scale for use with undergraduate STEM students in accordance with established standards for psychological measurement. This work will be conducted in three phases over two years. First, a large, diverse sample of undergraduate STEM students will be interviewed about how they think about intelligence, to refine the conceptual and operational definitions of mindset at the undergraduate level. Based on these results, survey items will be drafted and refined through cognitive interviews and sorting activities. The internal structure of the measure will be tested by surveying a second, national sample of undergraduate STEM students and conducting item response theory analyses on their responses. Finally, the resulting nomological network (representation of interrelationships between concepts and observations) will be tested by administering the new mindset instrument along with measures of related and unrelated constructs. Testing the nomological network for a construct of interest means that it should be distinct from and related in expected ways to other constructs. This new survey might be used by researchers to answer important questions about mindset in undergraduate students. Alternatively, instructors could use it to learn about the mindsets of undergraduates in their classes and tailor their instruction accordingly. Finally, practitioners could use it to develop and evaluate interventions that aim to increase student success by encouraging students to shift towards a growth mindset. 

The project is supported through the EHR Core Research: Building Capacity in STEM Education Research (ECR: BCSER) competition that is designed to build individuals' capacity to carry out high quality fundamental STEM education research in STEM learning and learning environments, broadening participation in STEM fields, and STEM workforce development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Students’ beliefs about their abilities – whether abilities are fixed or improvable (mindset), whether some people have more potential than others (universality), and whether innate, high intelligence is necessary for success in a field (brilliance) – all impact their experiences in the classroom and their educational outcomes. For example, students who believe their abilities can improve (growth mindset) view challenges in their learning process as a normal part of learning and are more likely to persist through challenges. “Mindset interventions” encourage students to adopt a growth mindset to promote academic success.

 

Effective research in this field requires precise and accurate tools to measure these beliefs. The existing mindset measure was developed for use with primary school children and does not work well with undergraduates. Universality and brilliance are more recently-developed ideas and high-quality measures have not been rigorously developed and tested. Further, it is unclear whether these more recently-developed ideas overlap with each other and mindset. Therefore, the goal of this project was to develop and test measures of mindset, universality and brilliance beliefs and explore how these beliefs differ.

 

Through four rounds of data collection and testing, we developed and collected extensive validity evidence for a new measure of these beliefs, the Undergraduate Lay Theories of Abilities (ULTrA) Survey. Through this process, we also produced to first evidence that mindset, universality, and brilliance are distinct beliefs that each relate to different psychological and academic outcomes. For example, mindset belief predicted students’ course grades, universality belief predicted students’ intent to persist in science, and brilliance belief predicted how concerned students felt about being judged for being wrong in class. These results are published in an open-access journal article:

Limeri, L. B., Carter, N. T., Lyra, F., Martin, J., Mastronardo, H., Patel, J., & Dolan, E. L. (2023). Undergraduate Lay Theories of Abilities: Mindset, universality, and brilliance beliefs uniquely predict undergraduate educational outcomes. CBE—Life Sciences Education, 22(4), ar40.

 

In addition, we compared the predictive power of the ULTrA survey to the original mindset measure with undergraduates. The ULTrA survey predicts all psychological the outcomes we measured twice as effectively as the original mindset measure. Further, the ULTrA predicts academic outcomes (course grade and persistence), which the original mindset measure does not predict. These results suggest measurement error could have been contributing to some instances of failure to replicate effects of mindset on undergraduate outcomes, rather than faults with the theory. These results have been submitted for publication in an open-access journal article.

 

Through this capacity-building project, PI Limeri, who is an early career researcher switching fields from Biology to Discipline-based Biology Education Research, learned about psychological measurement, measurement development, item response theory, and project management.

 

Intellectual Merit. This project is intellectually meritorious because it:

 - Produced a measure of undergraduates’ ability beliefs in accordance with best practices for establishing the validity;

 - Included a diverse group of undergraduates as study participants, which improved the validity and applicability of the resulting measure;

 - Improved the quality of research tools available to researchers. Previously, research on mindset in undergraduate STEM has been hampered by the lack of a high-quality measure;

 - Fostered collaboration between a biology education researcher and psychologists with expertise in psychological measurement, social psychology, and undergraduate STEM education; and,

 - Served as a quality example of measure development in discipline-based education research, which has been criticized for its lack of psychometric rigor.

 

Broader Impacts. This project had multiple broad impacts by: 

 - Producing a measure that can be used more reproducibly and reliably by researchers to gain a deeper understanding of college students’ mindset and test mindset interventions.

 - Producing a measure that can be used by instructors to evaluate how their pedagogical practices influence their students’ mindsets and use this knowledge to inform their practices;

 - Build the PI’s knowledge, skills, and abilities such that she will be able to develop these competencies to future generations of scholars during her career as a faculty member in biology education;

 - Establishing standards for measurement development in peer-reviewed discipline-based education research publications; and

 - Involving a team of undergraduate researchers, including students who belong to minoritized groups, as collaborators in the research.
